Record date: 2087-03-22
Internal Medicine
Reason for visit Diarrhea Fever Chest pain Fatigue
History of present illness The patient is here complaining of several days history of diarrhea with mild nausea, mild fever and retrosternal chest discomfort. That is intermittent mild and insiduous. The pain is not triggered by exercise or physical activity or position. She has been feeling weak.
Medical history Coronary vasospastic events
Glucose intolerance + postprandial hyperglycemia Hyperlipidemia Hypertension Postmenopausal Cervical osteoarthritis DDD Microscopic hematuria with negative work up Hypovitaminosis D Obesity - now loosing weight
Current meds
Amlodipine 5 mg qd Metoprolol XL 50 mg qd Valsartan 160 mg qd -combined Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg qd -combined Atorvastatin 20 mg qd Aspirin 81 mg qd Metformin 500 mg bid
Review of systems Denies abdominal pain, vomiting, dyspnea
Family and social history Place of birth GambiaHome residence JaffreyMarital status MarriedHousehold members HusbandOccupation Composer
Mother A dementia Father A diabetes Brothers 0 Sisters 1 Spouse A Children 2
Cancer 0 Diabetes + F + M CV Disease 0 Stroke 0
Labs and images Reviewed
Exam Vitals 110/72 96 16 98.0 HEENT eomi, conjunctiva pink, ears clear, nasal mucosa pink, no mucus, no sinus tenderness, no post nasal drip. Neck is supple, no JVD, no thyroid imprint, no submandibular nodes. Thorax expands symmetrically, clear to auscultation bilaterally. Pain reproduced on chest palpation. Cardiovascular S1 and S2 with regular rhythm and rate. No murmurs. Abdomen is soft, non tender, no palpable masses or organomegaly. Increased bowel sounds. Extremities are symmetrical with no edema. Neurological exam is grossly non focal.
Assessment and plan
Chest discomfort. The patient's history and exam do not suggest cardiovascular origin but pain originated in the chest wall, musculoskeletal in origin. She had an ECG in my office that was unchanged from previous ones, there were no ST-TW abnormalities, no extrasystoles or any other abnormality. She was reassured. For musculoskeletal pain I have recommended stretching exercises, and low dose diazepam for muscle contracture. She will avoid NSAID due to GI symptoms.
Abdominal discomfort with diarrhea. The patient will follow a CHO diet and will avoid dairy products and other substances with low-absorption high-residue. In addition, in context of weakness I have recommended her to have a chemistry analysis for investigating electrolytes. Should symptoms persist then I will recommend the patient to initiate Ciprofloxacin and Metronidazole.
Dehydration. The patient will initiate a strict fluid replenishment plan for rehydration.
David Delgado, M.D.
